tit.cmt: 漢字表記削除、タイトルの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 渡辺津（わたなべ・の・つ）は、摂津国の旧淀川河口近くに存在した、瀬戸内海沿岸で最大級の港湾。
sen.e: Watanabe no tsu (渡辺津), one of the biggest seaports on the coast of Seto Inland Sea, used to be located near the river mouth of the Kyu-Yodo-gawa River (旧淀川) (former Yodo-gawa River) in the Settsu Province (摂津国).
Watanabe no tsu, one of the biggest seaports on the coast of Seto Inland Sea, used to be located near the river mouth of the Kyu-Yodo-gawa River (former Yodo-gawa River) in the Settsu Province.
Watanabe no tsu, one of the biggest seaports on the coast of Seto Inland Sea, used to be located near the river mouth of the Kyu-Yodo-gawa River (former Yodo-gawa River) in the Settsu Province.

sen.j: 「窪津（九品津）」とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also called 'Kubotsu (窪津) (九品津).'
It is also called 'Kubotsu.'
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、全角クォーテーションを半角に修正
sen.e: It is also called 'Kubotsu.'

sen.j: 現在の大阪市の中心部、旧淀川にかかる天満橋から天神橋 (大阪府)の間くらいの位置にあった。
sen.e: Watanabe no tsu located at at the center of current Osaka City, between the Tenmabashi Bridge (天満橋) and the Tenjinbashi Bridge (天神橋) over Kyu-Yodo-gawa River.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Watanabe no tsu located at the center of current Osaka City, between the Tenma-bashi Bridge and the Tenjin-bashi Bridge over Kyu-Yodo-gawa River.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、at at→atに修正、Tenma-bashi Bridge, Tenjin-bashi Bridgeとしました。
sen.e: Watanabe no tsu located at the center of current Osaka City, between the Tenma-bashi Bridge and the Tenjin-bashi Bridge over Kyu-Yodo-gawa River.

sen.j: ここを中心とした北船場 (大阪市)一帯が入り江で、上町台地の北端の西部一帯に街が栄えていたと見られる。
sen.e: Kita Semba (北船場), Osaka City, centered around there, used to be a bay and there was a town, being flourished, on the western part of the north end of Uemachi plateau (上町台地).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kita Senba, Osaka City, centered around there, used to be a bay and there was a town, being flourished, on the western part of the north end of Uemachi plateau.
Kita Senba, Osaka City, centered around there, used to be a bay and there was a town, being flourished, on the western part of the north end of Uemachi plateau.

sen.j: かつて奈良時代まで難波津や難波京があった場所がそのまま首都・副都でなくなった後も港湾として機能し続けたものである。
sen.e: Naniwa no tsu (難波津) (Naniwa Port) or Naniwa-kyo (難波京) had located there up until the Nara period, and the place remained functioning as a seaport even after the transfer of the capital and secondary capital city.

Naniwa no tsu (Naniwa Port) and Naniwa-kyo had located there up until the Nara period, and the place remained functioning as a seaport even after the transfer of the capital and secondary capital city.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、or→andとしました。
sen.e: Naniwa no tsu (Naniwa Port) and Naniwa-kyo had located there up until the Nara period, and the place remained functioning as a seaport even after the transfer of the capital and secondary capital city.

sen.j: ここは瀬戸内と京都の間の水運の拠点で、海上・河川の船の積替え場であり、淀川を南北に渡る渡し場でもあった。
sen.e: Watanabe no tsu used to be the center of water transportation system between Setouchi (瀬戸内) and Kyoto, the delivery platform of the sea and river, and also the ferry connecting the north and south side of Yodo-gawa River.

Watanabe no tsu used to be the center of water transportation system between Setouchi and Kyoto, the delivery platform of the sea and river, and also the ferry connecting the north and south side of Yodo-gawa River.

Watanabe no tsu used to be the center of water transportation system between Setouchi and Kyoto, the delivery platform of the sea and river, and also the ferry connecting the north and south side of Yodo-gawa River.

sen.j: また、交通や経済のみならず、宗教的にも重要な場所であった。
sen.e: The place was important from transportation, economics and even religious point of view.
The place was important from transportation, economics and even religious point of view.
The place was important from transportation, economics and even religious point of view.

sen.j: 京から四天王寺・住吉大社・熊野三山へ詣でる際は淀川からの船をここで降りていたため、熊野古道もこの渡辺津が起点だった。
sen.e: Watanabe no tsu was also the starting point for Kumanokodo Road (熊野古道), because the worshippers from Kyoto visiting Shitenno-ji Temple (四天王寺), Sumiyoshitaisha Shrine (住吉大社) and Kumano Sanzan (熊野三山) (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha Shrine, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha Shrine and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha Shrine) got off boats at here.

Watanabe no tsu was also the starting point for Kumanokodo Road, because the worshippers from Kyoto visiting Shitenno-ji Temple, Sumiyoshi Taisha Shrine and Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha Shrine, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha Shrine and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha Shrine) got off boats at here.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、Sumiyoshi Taisha Shrineとしました。
sen.e: Watanabe no tsu was also the starting point for Kumanokodo Road, because the worshippers from Kyoto visiting Shitenno-ji Temple, Sumiyoshi Taisha Shrine and Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha Shrine, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha Shrine and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha Shrine) got off boats at here.

sen.j: 後日港の近くの台地の上に石山本願寺が築かれ、浄土真宗の本拠となった。
sen.e: Later, Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple (石山本願寺) was built on a highland near the port and became the base of Jodo Shinshu (浄土真宗) (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).
Later, Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple was built on a highland near the port and became the base of Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、「浄土真宗」→統一リストの表記に修正
sen.e: Later, Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple was built on a highland near the port and became the base of Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

sen.j: 軍事的にも重要な港であった。
sen.e: It was also important for military purpose.
It was also important for military purpose.
It was also important for military purpose.

sen.j: 平安時代後期には源氏嵯峨源氏の源綱（渡辺綱）がこの地に住んで渡辺を名字とし、渡辺氏を起こした。
sen.e: In the late Heian period, MINAMOTO no Tsuna (源綱) (WATANABE no Tsuna (渡辺綱)) of Saga-Genji (嵯峨源氏), the Minamoto clan (源氏), lived there and started the Watanabe clan (渡辺氏) by changing his Family name to Watanabe.
In the late Heian period, MINAMOTO no Tsuna (WATANABE no Tsuna) of Saga-Genji, the Minamoto clan, lived there and started the Watanabe clan by changing his family name to Watanabe.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、Family→familyとしました。
sen.e: In the late Heian period, MINAMOTO no Tsuna (WATANABE no Tsuna) of Saga-Genji, the Minamoto clan, lived there and started the Watanabe clan by changing his family name to Watanabe.

sen.j: 渡辺綱の子孫は渡辺党と呼ばれる武士団に発展し、港に立地することから水軍として日本全国に散らばり、瀬戸内海の水軍の棟梁となる。
sen.e: The descendants of the Watanabe clan grew into a bushidan (武士団) (warrior bands) called Watanabe-to Party (渡辺党), and since they located at seaports, scattered everywhere in Japan as Suigun (水軍) (warriors battle in the sea) and became the toryo (棟梁) (leader) of the Suigun in the Seto Inland Sea (瀬戸内海).

The descendants of WATANABE no Tsuna grew into a bushidan (warrior bands) called Watanabe-to Party, and since they located at seaports, scattered everywhere in Japan as Suigun (warriors battle in the sea) and became the toryo (leader) of the Suigun in the Seto Inland Sea.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、the Watanabe clan→WATANABE no Tsunaに修正
sen.e: The descendants of WATANABE no Tsuna grew into a bushidan (warrior bands) called Watanabe-to Party, and since they located at seaports, scattered everywhere in Japan as Suigun (warriors battle in the sea) and became the toryo (leader) of the Suigun in the Seto Inland Sea.

sen.j: その代表的な支族は北九州の松浦氏であり、松浦氏を惣領とする松浦党である。
sen.e: The representative branch family of the Watanabe clan is the Matsuura clan (松浦氏) and the Matsuura Party (Matsuura Party), inherited by the Matsuura clan, located at the northern Kyushu.
The representative branch family of the Watanabe clan is the Matsuura clan and the Matsuura Party, inherited by the Matsuura clan, located at the northern Kyushu.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、the Matsuura Party (Matsuura Party)→the Matsuura Partyに修正
sen.e: The representative branch family of the Watanabe clan is the Matsuura clan and the Matsuura Party, inherited by the Matsuura clan, located at the northern Kyushu.

sen.j: 豊臣氏家臣の渡辺氏や徳川氏譜代の渡辺氏もまた子孫と伝える。
sen.e: It is said that the Watanabe clan, the vassal of the Toyotomi clan, and the Watanabe clan, the daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family, are also the descendants of MINAMOTO no Tsuna.
It is said that the Watanabe clan, the vassal of the Toyotomi clan, and the Watanabe clan, the daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family, are also the descendants of MINAMOTO no Tsuna.
It is said that the Watanabe clan, the vassal of the Toyotomi clan, and the Watanabe clan, the daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family, are also the descendants of MINAMOTO no Tsuna.

sen.j: この地にあった有名な神社が坐摩神社（社号は「いかすり」と読むが、通常は「ざま」）である。
sen.e: The famous shrine located in that location was Ikasuri-jinja Shrine (坐摩神社) (Its shago (社号) (shrine's name) is 'Ikasuri (坐摩)' but it is usually called 'Zama (坐摩).')
The famous shrine located in that location was Ikasuri-jinja Shrine (Its shago [shrine's name] is 'Ikasuri' but it is usually called 'Zama').
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、カッコ表記、全角クォーテーション修正、ピリオドの位置を移動
sen.e: The famous shrine located in that location was Ikasuri-jinja Shrine (Its shago [shrine's name] is 'Ikasuri' but it is usually called 'Zama').

sen.j: かつての本殿は、渡辺津のあった場所（天神橋東南の渡辺町、現在の石町）にあったが、豊臣秀吉の大坂城築城の際に現在地（大阪市営地下鉄本町駅の南）に移転した。
sen.e: Its honden (本殿) (main shrine) was located in the place where Watanabe no tsu used to be - Watanabe-cho (渡辺町) (present 石町) located at the south-east of the Tenjinbashi Bridge, but it was moved to the present location - the south of the Hommachi-eki Station of Osaka (Municipal) Subway (大阪市営地下鉄本町駅), when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI built Osaka-jo Castle.

Its honden (main shrine) was located in the place where Watanabe no tsu used to be - Watanabe-cho (present Koku-machi) located at the south-east of the Tenjin-bashi Bridge, but it was moved to the present location - the south of the Honmachi Station of Osaka (Municipal) Subway, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI built Osaka-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、石町→Koku-machiに修正、Tenjin-bashi Bridge、Honmachi Stationとしました。
sen.e: Its honden (main shrine) was located in the place where Watanabe no tsu used to be - Watanabe-cho (present Koku-machi) located at the south-east of the Tenjin-bashi Bridge, but it was moved to the present location - the south of the Honmachi Station of Osaka (Municipal) Subway, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI built Osaka-jo Castle.

sen.j: 大阪が歴史の表舞台に登場するのには、難波京から石山本願寺まで空白期間がある。
sen.e: Osaka didn't play a major part in the history between the era of Naniwa-kyo and Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple.
Osaka did not play a major part in the history between the era of Naniwa-kyo and Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple.
Osaka did not play a major part in the history between the era of Naniwa-kyo and Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: 大阪湾の港も兵庫区や神崎 (尼崎市)、堺市が注目されるが、平安時代や鎌倉時代、室町時代の間も渡辺津がひきつづき淀川河口における港湾の機能を果たし続けていた。
sen.e: Although the seaports in Hyogo Ward (兵庫区), Kanzaki (神崎) in Amagasaki City (尼崎市), and Sakai City (堺市) attract attention in the Osaka Bay (大阪湾), Watanabe no tsu was continuously functioning as the seaport at the river mouth of the Yodo-gawa River through the Heian period (平安時代), the Kamakura period (鎌倉時代) and the Muromachi period (室町時代).

Although the seaports in Hyogo Ward, Kanzaki in Amagasaki City, and Sakai City attract attention in the Osaka Bay, Watanabe no tsu was continuously functioning as the seaport at the river mouth of the Yodo-gawa River through the Heian period, the Kamakura period and the Muromachi period.

Although the seaports in Hyogo Ward, Kanzaki in Amagasaki City, and Sakai City attract attention in the Osaka Bay, Watanabe no tsu was continuously functioning as the seaport at the river mouth of the Yodo-gawa River through the Heian period, the Kamakura period and the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 中之島 (大阪府)を渡る四つ橋筋の橋に「渡辺橋」があるが、これは渡辺津の繁栄にちなみ江戸時代につけられた名前で、渡辺津のあった場所からは若干下流に当たる。
sen.e: One of the four bridges that go through Nakanoshima (中之島) (Osaka Prefecture) is the Watanabe-bashi Bridge (渡辺橋), named after the prosperity of Watanabe no tsu in the Edo period, located in the place slightly downstream from the place where Watanabe no tsu used to be.

One of the four bridges that go through Nakanoshima (Osaka Prefecture) is the Watanabe-bashi Bridge, named after the prosperity of Watanabe no tsu in the Edo period, located in the place slightly downstream from the place where Watanabe no tsu used to be.

One of the four bridges that go through Nakanoshima (Osaka Prefecture) is the Watanabe-bashi Bridge, named after the prosperity of Watanabe no tsu in the Edo period, located in the place slightly downstream from the place where Watanabe no tsu used to be.

sen.j: 上記、坐摩神社のある場所も「渡辺」というが、ここも豊臣秀吉によって渡辺の地名ごと現在地に移転させられたもので本来の渡辺津からは離れている。
sen.e: The place where Ikasuri-jinja Shrine is located is also called 'Watanabe,' and the name itself was also moved with the shrine from its original location by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and it is separated from the location where Watanabe no tsu was originally located.

The place where Ikasuri-jinja Shrine is located is also called 'Watanabe,' and the name itself was also moved with the shrine from its original location by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and it is separated from the location where Watanabe no tsu was originally located.
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正
sen.e: The place where Ikasuri-jinja Shrine is located is also called 'Watanabe,' and the name itself was also moved with the shrine from its original location by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and it is separated from the location where Watanabe no tsu was originally located.

sen.j: 現在の住所は大阪市中央区久太郎町4丁目渡辺だが、1988年の地名変更まではここを渡辺町といっていた。
sen.e: The present address of the shrine is Watanabe 4 Kyutaromachi, Chuo Ward, Osaka City (大阪市中央区久太郎町4丁目渡辺), but the area was called Watanabe-cho up until 1988.
The present address of the shrine is Watanabe, 4-chome Kyutaromachi, Chuo Ward, Osaka City, but the area was called Watanabe-cho up until 1988.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、カンマ追加、4→4-chomeとしました。
sen.e: The present address of the shrine is Watanabe, 4-chome Kyutaromachi, Chuo Ward, Osaka City, but the area was called Watanabe-cho up until 1988.

sen.j: 渡辺の名のルーツが消えるのに反対する運動が渡辺氏の末裔の間で起こり、結局丁目の後ろの番地の変わりに渡辺の名が残ることになった。
sen.e: There was a protest campaign by the descendants of the Watanabe clan against that the roots of the Watanabe clan to be disappeared, and eventually, the name of Watanabe remained in the address replacing the block number.

There was a protest campaign by the descendants of the Watanabe clan against that the roots of the Watanabe clan to be disappeared, and eventually, the name of Watanabe remained in the address replacing the block number.

There was a protest campaign by the descendants of the Watanabe clan against that the roots of the Watanabe clan to be disappeared, and eventually, the name of Watanabe remained in the address replacing the block number.

sen.j: 江戸時代以降、大坂市街地の南にかつて「渡辺村」と呼ばれた被差別部落民の集落があり皮革製造、太鼓製造などを行ってきたが、ここも本来の渡辺津の場所からはかなり離れている。
sen.e: After the Edo period, on the south of the urban area of Osaka city, there was a settlement of Burakumin (被差別部落民) (modern-day descendants of Japan's feudal outcast group) called 'Watanabe-mura Village (渡辺村),' manufacturing leather, drums and such, and this place also was a good distance from the location where Watanabe no tsu used to be.

After the Edo period, on the south of the urban area of Osaka City, there was a settlement of Burakumin (modern-day descendants of Japan's feudal outcast group) called 'Watanabe-mura Village,' manufacturing leather, drums and such, and this place also was a good distance from the location where Watanabe no tsu used to be.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記削除、Osaka Cityとし、全角クォーテーションを半角に修正
sen.e: After the Edo period, on the south of the urban area of Osaka City, there was a settlement of Burakumin (modern-day descendants of Japan's feudal outcast group) called 'Watanabe-mura Village,' manufacturing leather, drums and such, and this place also was a good distance from the location where Watanabe no tsu used to be.

sen.j: ただし、地元の言い伝えでは、渡辺村の住民はもともと渡辺津に住んでいたのを移転させられたそうである。
sen.e: However, according to the local legend, the residents of the Watanabe-mura Village were moved from the original location of Watanabe no tsu to the place where the settlement used to be.
However, according to the local legend, the residents of the Watanabe-mura Village were moved from the original location of Watanabe no tsu to the place where the settlement used to be.
However, according to the local legend, the residents of the Watanabe-mura Village were moved from the original location of Watanabe no tsu to the place where the settlement used to be.
